theme: You have indicated that you are happy to receive news and updates from the ESRC Education Research Programme. To unsubscribe, please email Elizabeth.hudson@ucl.ac.uk with the word UNSUBSCRIBE in the title of the email.
title: Do you find this newsletter useful? Are you happy with its frequency? Which section do you find most useful? Any pressing topics we haven't covered? Any good sources of information you think we're missing? How could we improve? We advocate for listening to different stakeholders and so we want your views too!
description: Answer these short questions

title: Event - The Curriculum Review: What works, what's missing, what's next?
description: 17 March 17.30-19.00 Online The latest in the panel discussion series, What matters in education? Join an expert panel from the IOE to discuss the implications of the Curriculum Review Interim Report for teaching and learning in primary, secondary, post-16 sectors and for pupils with SEND. The Review asked for input from a wide range on interested parties, including parents and pupils, as well as teachers and experts in curriculum and assessment. The panel will discuss progress made so far and what might need to happen next to lead to sustainable change.

title: NFER blog - Special School Teachers: Where do they come from? Where do they go?
description: Michael Scott There are around 25,000 teachers and 75,000 other staff work in state-funded special schools in England, but little work has looked at the workforce challenges in special schools.

title: IOE – Centre for Education Policy and Equalising Opportunities blog Why do teachers in some schools keep getting better for longer?
description: Sam Sims Research shows that teachers rapidly become more effective over the first few years of their career. After that, the rate of growth tends to slow down. However, in certain schools, teachers keep getting better for longer . What is different about these schools? And can it be emulated by other schools?

title: CCT – EdTech Evidence Board: Contribute to the survey of the new or respond to the call for evidence
description: Currently in Phase One, working to develop the criteria that will be used to assess EdTech products. Looking for contributions from all different stakeholders to ensure guidance and processes are useful to all, and that gathering evidence of impact can ultimately be incorporated into product development and testing across the EdTech sector.

title: Ada Lovelace Blog - Learning and teaching with AI - A call for a rights-respecting approach
description: Ayça Atabey Suggests that regulations should require that AI developers adhere to ethical guidelines and comply with standards that centre on transparency, accountability and fairness, and protect students' privacy and autonomy.

title: TLS article - Teacher's friend or enemy? AI could revolutionize the classroom
description: Robert Ades reviews 'Brave New Words' by Salman Khan and considers the role of AI in the classroom, particularly the potential for their use to reduce the relationships pupils form with their teachers.

title: The Youth Shadow Panel Interim report: Summarising our youth-led call for evidence
description: This interim report sets out what KS1-KS5 students in England think about their learning and assessment, and is a contribution to the Curriculum Review.

title: Oxford School of Thought report – Requires Improvement: Why primary schools need a distinct model of inspection
description: OST proposes a model of school inspection for primary schools, highlighting the need for a framework that reflects the unique nature of primary education.

title: Welsh parliament - Implementation of education reforms consultation
description: The Children, Young People and Education Committee has agreed monitor the implementation of two key education reforms as they are being rolled out throughout the sixth Senedd: The Curriculum and Assessment (Wales) Act 2021; and The Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018. Anyone with an interest in either the new curriculum or the ALN reforms – such as educators, stakeholders, pupils or parents - can submit their views on any element of the rollout of the education reforms at any point on their implementation journeys.

title: WonkHE blog - Research flexibility doesn't have to mean researcher precarity
description: James Coe and David Kernohan look for the balance between flexibility and predictability that can allow researchers, research, and the wider economy to thrive

title: SchoolsWeek opinion piece - Policy must better promote local SEND collaboration
description: Abrilli Phillip, Director of education, London Borough of Lambeth & Dr Sam Parrett, Group CEO, London South East Colleges Our recent work in Lambeth shows that government could quickly drive up SEND capacity nationally by incentivising partnerships between LAs and trusts

title: EPI Report - Who has been registered for free school meals and pupil premium in the National Pupil Database? Implications for research and policy
description: In this large project, funded by Nuffield, EPI are considering whether current measures of poverty sufficiently identify and serve educationally disadvantaged and under-resourced pupils. They are considering ways to improve uses of the FSM measure, and potential alternatives.

title: NFER blog - We can't close the disadvantage gap if we don't know what's driving it
description: Jude Hillary Reducing the attainment gap has been a priority for several recent governments. This week's release of new data on secondary school attainment outcomes for 2023/24 should be a key metric for judging their progress on this priority. Sadly, the measure just isn't fit for that purpose.

title: Schools APPG with APPG for Parents Meeting - 'The Missing Chapter' and the Child Poverty Strategy
description: 25 March, Parliament 10.30am This session will explore research by Parentkind, supported by the NEU, on parental and family experiences of poverty. The findings highlight the hidden costs of schooling as a critical child poverty issue and recommend its inclusion in the upcoming Child Poverty Strategy.

theme: You have indicated that you are happy to receive news and updates from the ESRC Education Research Programme. To unsubscribe, please email Elizabeth.hudson@ucl.ac.uk with the word UNSUBSCRIBE in the title of the email.
title: Do you find this newsletter useful? Are you happy with its frequency? Which section do you find most useful? Any pressing topics we haven't covered? Any good sources of information you think we're missing? How could we improve? We advocate for listening to different stakeholders and so we want your views too!
description: Answer these short questions

title: Event - The Curriculum Review: What works, what's missing, what's next?
description: 17 March 17.30-19.00 Online The latest in the panel discussion series, What matters in education? will focus on the next stage in the DfE's Curriculum Review. With the Interim Report due shortly, join an expert panel from the IOE to discuss progress made so far and what might need to happen next to lead to sustainable change.

subtheme: Updates from the ERP projects Investigating the recruitment and retention of minority ethnic teachers, and its relationship to school outcomes PI: Stephen Gorard
title: Yorkshire Post - How do we tackle issues impacting minority ethnic children in education?
description: A multi-ethnic team of academics from Durham and Birmingham universities have found that poverty and special educational needs (SEND), rather than ethnicity alone, are the key influences on a minority ethnic child's educational outcomes.

title: The Teaching Commission -
description: The Commission is looking at what must be done to recreate teaching as an attractive and sustainable profession. It has highlighted that the sector is missing out on a huge pool of talent as a result failing to tackle racism in a meaningful way.

title: NFER - 7th Teacher Labour Market in England Annual Report 2025
description: The NFER Annual Report highlights that England's school system faces a substantial and growing challenge of ensuring there are sufficient numbers of teachers employed in schools. Recruitment into initial teacher training (ITT) remains persistently poor. Guardian report

title: Sky News - A potential bill to ban children from social media
description: A Labour MP has had to water down plans for a social media ban on under 16s and a smartphone ban in schools in order for his safer phones bill to get government support Defend Digital Me - A Code of Practice on Children's Data and Education: what's next? The government committed to instructing the ICO to create a Code of Practice for Data Protection in education, but concerns remain about its effectiveness and scope, particularly regarding the comprehensive protection of pupils' data throughout the entire educational process. More

title: SchoolsWeek - Ofsted open to 'another consultation' on inspection reforms if sector demands rethink
description: Watchdog's national director also insists report card proposals do not 'throw the baby out with the bath water'

title: Have your say - two consultations are open from the DfE and Ofsted
description: Ofsted are asking parents, carers, professionals and learners what they think about their proposals to improve education inspections and their new report cards Consultation details

title: Deadline: 28 April 2025
description: The DfE are running a separate consultation seeking views on school accountability principles, school profiles and a stronger approach to school improvement through intervention for state schools across England. Consultation details

title: Deadline: 28 April 2025
description: Schoolsweek summary of the DfE consultation

title: Welsh Parliament - Smartphone "ban" is not the right call for schools
description: An outright "ban" on smartphones in all schools is not a clear cut call, says the Senedd's Petitions Committee, who instead want to see more support for schools to set their own restrictions. Education NI – TransformED NI Transforming teaching and learning: a strategy for Educational Excellence in Northern Ireland TransformED NI outlines a comprehensive strategy for the transformation of teaching and learning in Northern Ireland. The strategy focuses on the core areas of curriculum, assessment, qualifications, school improvement and tackling educational disadvantage. Transforming teaching and learning: a strategy for Educational Excellence in Northern Ireland Belfast Telegraph coverage BBC News – Scotland: 'Failure to plan' over soaring pupil support needs Audit Scotland found around 40% of Scottish pupils are now receiving additional support for learning (ASL), most of it delivered within mainstream schools. The report calls for ministers to "fundamentally rethink" how they fund and staff provision to meet demand.

title: Four Lessons from What Works Centres on Understanding Impact
description: In this UPEN blog, Eleanor MacKillop from the Wales Centre for Public Policy summarises four lessons in planning, generating and evaluating impact that she hopes are useful for all organisations that broker evidence into policy.

title: BERA Blog - School health and wellbeing, and national education system reform in Wales
description: Sarah Jayne Long considers preparation for, and implementation of, the Curriculum for Wales with an explicit focus on health and wellbeing. Her research suggests that education system reform requires change at multiple levels of the education system, and that consideration of each level, and the interactions between them, is necessary for achieving change.

title: Barnardos report- Nourishing the Future: making healthy food accessible for every child
description: This report draws on insights from children, young people, parents and Barnardo's practitioners, and experts in child health and nutrition as part of the growing evidence that here in the UK, far too many children and young people are missing out on the nutritious food they need to thrive.

title: The All-Party Parliamentary Group (APPG) for Education: New call for evidence on an inquiry into the Love of Learning.
description: Deadline: 22nd April 2025. Education is currently in crisis. More and more students are being homeschooled, attendance is falling and concerns around SEND and mental health for staff and pupils are rising.

title: SchoolsWeek - DfE told to come clean on its SEND reforms plan
description: Education committee chair asks government to 'set out its plans and anticipated timescales' for special needs reforms

title: FED Event - Power in Place – Driving Effective Education Partnerships for Flourishing Learners and Communities
description: 25 March 16.00-17.30 Across the country, collaboration between schools, colleges, and communities often happens despite the system, rather than because of it. This roundtable discussion will explore how we can move beyond isolated success stories to create a future where effective place-based partnerships are the foundation of a strong, inclusive education system. More

title: Guardian report
description: nan

title: Defend Digital Me - A Code of Practice on Children's Data and Education: what's next? The government committed to instructing the ICO to create a Code of Practice for Data Protection in education, but concerns remain about its effectiveness and scope, particularly regarding the comprehensive protection of pupils' data throughout the entire educational process. More
description: nan

title: Education NI – TransformED NI Transforming teaching and learning: a strategy for Educational Excellence in Northern Ireland TransformED NI outlines a comprehensive strategy for the transformation of teaching and learning in Northern Ireland. The strategy focuses on the core areas of curriculum, assessment, qualifications, school improvement and tackling educational disadvantage. Transforming teaching and learning: a strategy for Educational Excellence in Northern Ireland Belfast Telegraph coverage BBC News – Scotland: 'Failure to plan' over soaring pupil support needs Audit Scotland found around 40% of Scottish pupils are now receiving additional support for learning (ASL), most of it delivered within mainstream schools. The report calls for ministers to "fundamentally rethink" how they fund and staff provision to meet demand.

description: Answer these short questions

title: AI in Education: From chalkboards to chatbots, does anything really change? 29 April 12.30-13.30 Online
description: Speakers: Dominik Lukes , Lead Business Technologist, AI and ML Competency Centre, University of Oxford: The general rise of AI and EdTech Graham Purves , Head of The Grammar School at Leeds Principal elect of Leicester Grammar School Trust: EdTech use in schools - the challenges and potential and how it is changing (or not) the flows of teaching Ted Palenski , Postgraduate researcher in Digital Citizenship: Data Ethics in the Classroom and Beyond Email Elizabeth.hudson@ucl.ac.uk for the event link

title: The What Matters in Education panel discussion event : The Curriculum Review: What works, what's missing, what's next?
description: happened just before the Interim Report was published. If you couldn't make the event, catch up with the video here.

theme: Towards equity focused approaches to EdTech: a socio-technical perspective PI: Rebecca Eynon
title: A response to the UK Parliament's call for evidence: Solving the SEND crisis
description: The project's submission to the parliamentary enquiry highlighted four key areas of technology use in secondary schools that matter in SEND support: the disparities in digital infrastructure between schools, the tension between digital inclusion and digital stigma, inadequate 'personalisation' of adaptive software, and the lack of evidence for schools to draw on when making decisions about EdTech. Full response Congratulations to Rebecca, who has received funding from Oxford University's Social Sciences Business Engagement Seed Fund for her project 'Engaging with EdTech companies to build equitable technologies for schooling'

theme: Sustainable school leadership: comparing approaches to the training, supply and retention of senior school leaders across the UK PI Toby Greany
title: TES - How we built a local school ecosystem to drive improvement
description: Reports on a model of locality system leadership that Toby Greany and colleague Susan Cousin have been pioneering in Ealing . The TES reports "Ealing Learning Partnership has led to numerous successes for schools in one of London's most diverse and complex boroughs. Its founders explain how"

theme: Embedding children's participation rights in pedagogical practice in lower primary classrooms in Wales PI: Sarah Chicken
title: Event - CRN Curriculum & Pedagogy: Young Children's Participative Rights in Schools
description: 27 March 16.30-18.00 Join us for an online CRN Curriculum & Pedagogy seminar sharing findings from a three-year project, 'Children's Participation in Schools'.

title: SchoolsWeek - Schools can afford less than half of proposed 2.8% pay rise, admits DfE
description: 'Headroom' in next year's budget only leaves enough for an increase of 1.3 per cent, official government analysis finds

title: 5Rights - UK Online Safety Act takes effect as tech industry keeps shifting blame to parents
description: As tech CEOs continue shifting responsibility onto parents, 5Rights calls on Ofcom to robustly enforce this code and hold companies accountable for protecting children from harm.

title: BBC Push for a ban on mobile phones
description: The Conservative Party will attempt to amend the Labour government's Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill to include a ban on mobile phones in schools

title: Schools Week - Curriculum review signals primary content cut and fewer GCSE exams
description: Interim report also signals changes to the EBacc and a subject-by-subject review amid concerns over balance of content 14 key things school leaders need to know ...

title: DfE - Young people to benefit from creative education boost
description: New package announced to support young people to access high-quality arts education and enrichment activities as well as AI and tech opportunities.

title: The Guardian - The Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill under attack
description: Ofsted ex-chief Amanda Spielman says schools bill 'very likely' to make education in England worse

title: Schools Week - Academy Executive Pay investigated
description: Their analysis suggests the gap is widening between CEOs and the rest in the highest-paying trusts.

title: Belfast Telegraph - New maths and English tests for some NI pupils as Education Minister re-offers teacher pay deal
description: Paul Givan said the tests will "provide insights into learning outcomes across the education system" and "will play a vital role in shaping educational policies and interventions".

title: EPI report – Breaking down the gap
description: The latest report by EPI calls on the government to address the underlying causes of school absences. It identifies higher levels of absence to be a key factor in the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their peers. More

title: IPPR – Who is losing learning: Finding solutions to the school engagement crisis
description: A set of wide ranging recommendations on school admissions, accountability, inclusion, timely intervention, teacher recruitment for underserved schools, and better support services to solve the engagement crisis The Royal Society 's response to the Spending Review consultation is wide-ranging, including a call to " Substantially increase the current very minimal education research budget . Monitoring and evaluating the impact of education policy reforms, including from the CAR, will ensure that these are truly effective and deliver tangible improvements for children and young people." More

title: Child of the North and the Centre for Young Lives report - An evidence-based approach to creating a culture of inclusive opportunity through arts and creativity
description: This report sets out the benefits to be gained from placing creativity and the arts at the centre of our education system and how the Born in Bradford initiative has been driving forward evidence-based approaches to improving outcomes for all children.

title: CCT blog – SEND Roundtable write-up
description: CCT hosted a SEND-focussed roundtable with colleagues from the Department for Education (DfE). Representatives from primary, secondary, further education, specialist provision, and hospital schooling shared their first-hand experiences of SEND provision in school settings nationwide. The blog shares best practice now and an analysis of what would make the system better.

title: BBC More or Less Podcast - How did lockdown impact children?
description: Five years on, Tim Harford delves into the data to try to work out what we can say with confidence about the effect of the lockdown on the children and young adults who lived through it. On questions of education levels, job prospects and mental health, what story does the best evidence show us?

title: The ESRC Education Research Programme ECR Network cordially invites you for a special open session, featuring a panel of speakers on AI and the implications for teaching and learning in schools.

title: Do you find this newsletter useful? Are you happy with its frequency? Which section do you find most useful? Any pressing topics we haven't covered? Any good sources of information you think we're missing? How could we improve? We advocate for listening to different stakeholders and so we want your views too!
description: Answer these short questions

theme: Rethinking teacher recruitment: New approaches to attracting prospective STEM teachers PI: Rob Klassen
title: Teach First Lunch and Learn: The five-year-itch: Retaining Early Career Teachers
description: 1 April 11-11.50 Rebecca Snell will be presenting at Teach First's Lunch & Learn on her BERJ paper The five-year-itch: Retaining Early Career Teachers Link to join

title: FED event - How can we address the growing teacher recruitment and retention challenge? What the latest data is telling us.
description: 31 March 4-5.30 (Online) NFER researchers Jack Worth & Natasha Armstrong talk about their most recent report Book

title: DfE Consultation - Narrowing the digital divide in schools and colleges
description: This consultation sets out the Department for Education's long-term vision for narrowing the digital divide in schools and colleges, focusing on proposals for the future of the digital and technology standards . Deadline: 23 May 2025

title: The Education Hub – DfE blog - Breaking down the digital divide in schools: What you need to know
description: DfE have committed £45 million to improve digital connectivity in schools to close the digital divide over the next year.

title: HEPI blog - However: The Curriculum and Assessment review
description: Chris Husbands takes a look at the new Interim Report of the Curriculum and Assessment Review. He concludes that the report is "thorough, technical and thoughtful" but leaves many questions unanswered. "To simplify: attainment gaps open early; they are not closed by the curriculum and assessment system, and one of the few graphs in the report (p 18) suggests that they are widening, leaving behind a large minority of learners who struggle to access a qualifications system which is not working for them. "

title: SchoolsWeek - 'Evolution' may not be quick enough to meet our challenges
description: Tony Breslin argues that the language of school improvement needs to change: "The existing language of school improvement frames current levels of pupil absenteeism as a crisis of school attendance; a new language would frame it as an issue of educational engagement." He questions whether the current government's approach to system reform goes far enough

title: Demos report - Mission-ready nation
description: The report explores what Labour's approach to mission-led government might mean for system reform, and how to harness the power of collective action to make it happen.

title: Institute for Government - The role reviews can play as a valuable tool for policymaking
description: An IFG blog sets out the contribution that consultations, internal reviews and independent reviews can make to good policymaking. Sign up for their expert panel discussion on Government reviews: Dither and delay, or route to reform? 3 April 14.00 – 15.00 (Hybrid)

title: Scottish Government blog – Refreshing Scotland's Digital Strategy, part 2
description: Guest blog post by Colin Birchenall, Chief Technology Officer, the Digital Office for Scottish Local Government. At the heart of Scotland's Digital Strategy is the recognition that digital is a fundamental enabler for achieving the country's priorities. Whether it is economic growth, social inclusion, or environmental sustainability, digital solutions play a crucial role in driving progress and innovation across all sectors.

title: Welsh Government - Policy and strategy for Artificial intelligence (AI)
description: The Welsh Government explores how AI could be used across government and the public sector in Wales and sets out the principles they are using to help guide the responsible use of AI

title: Dept for Education NI news - Givan launches a new programme to increase access for teachers to the latest education research.
description: The Making Best Practice, Common Practice programme aims to help bridge the gap between academic research and classroom practice, ensuring that educators are equipped with the latest evidence-based strategies to enhance learning for all pupils.

title: Research England - Strengthening data and insights into our changing university research landscape
description: Research England's Executive Chair sets out some of the unprecedented challenges facing HEIs and why this is leading them to investigate how universities are spending their QR funding

title: Local Policy Innovation Partnership Hub - What Is Innovation in Policy?
description: This blog provides a round up of how the Local Policy Innovation Partnerships (LPIPS) rethinking how policies are conceived, developed, and delivered. Funded by ESRC, Innovate UK and the AHRC, this initiative is hoping to encourage collaboration between governments, businesses, academia, and communities, breaking down silos and ensuring diverse perspectives inform decision-making.

title: University of Birmingham event - Capability and Capacity Building in Place Leadership: Identity, Inclusion and Change
description: 10 Apr 9:30 - 17:00 PM University of Birmingham Speakers will present and discuss evidence-based examples of place-based leadership and how this can contribute to political stability and inclusive and sustainable economic growth locally and regionally, particularly through partnership working.

title: DfE - Pupil absence in schools in England: 2023 to 2024 Statistics on the levels of overall, authorised and unauthorised absence in state-funded schools.
description: nan

title: Institute for Government analysis paper - Policy making for left-behind groups: School readiness
description: How can government start closing the opportunity gap in early years education?

title: The ERP's double symposium entitled: ' Doing Policy Relevant Research: Using knowledge mobilisation and knowledge exchange strategies to translate findings into actionable insights.' Part One. Technology in education and Part Two. Teachers and Teaching will be presented at BERA 2025. The symposia will combine insights from seven projects in the programme.
description: The ERP have created a new Knowledge Exchange Resource Hub . This brings together a range of resources we are aware of that are designed to support research engagement with different stakeholders. We welcome other suggestions. Please get in touch if you are aware of other resources that we are missing.

title: Children's Participation in Schools Annual Symposium 2025
description: Catch up with the video of the team's annual symposium featuring talks from some of their teacher participants.

title: Public Accounts Committee Inquiry - Increasing teacher numbers: Secondary and further education
description: Deadline: 5 May 2025

title: SchoolsWeek - Teacher union reports 'surge' in concerns about redundancies
description: NASUWT leader says he raised 'serious concerns' with government about funding in December

title: SchoolsWeek - DfE calls for evidence to aid National Professional Qualifications (NPQ) review
description: The DfE is asking for 'recent, relevant and high-quality research' as it reviews its suite of NPQs - beginning with those focused on leadership Consultation

title: Ada Lovelace Institute blog - The case for a local government AI taskforce
description: A nine minute read on what successful collaboration on using AI across local and central government might look like and the key principles to be borne in mind along the way

title: Sir Martyn Oliver's speech to Parentkind
description: Sir Martyn Oliver, Ofsted's Chief Inspector, spoke to Parentkind on the role of parents in education. He emphasised that smartphones have no place in schools and Ofsted will back headteachers who take a tough line on smartphones in their schools. Parentkind has now called on the Secretary of State for Education, Rt Hon Bridget Phillipson MP, to make this an urgent priority.

title: House of Commons Library - Which children are most likely to be in poverty in the UK?
description: The government's child poverty strategy is due to be published in spring 2025. The latest data shows 31% of children were in relative poverty after housing costs in 2023/24.

title: The Nuffield Foundation responds to SEND Inquiry
description: The Foundation has funded many grants on SEND, and drew on their findings in their response, which focused on 3 key themes; Where and how SEND is identified, Workforce challenges, and Funding the SEND system. Transatlantic news on how changes to federal funding for education are impacting on Education Resources Information Center (ERIC) - a major education research database, with its origins in the civil rights movement in the US

title: Scottish Government - Child poverty in Scotland falls
description: Annual statistics published today show that compared with the previous year's statistics, relative child poverty in 2023-24 reduced from 26% to 22% in Scotland while absolute child poverty fell from 23% to 17%. UK Poverty statistics published today show levels of relative child poverty at 31% and absolute child poverty at 26%.

title: Belfast Telegraph - It's the workload, stupid: Many teachers would forgo pay deal for a curb on rising list of responsibilities
description: Union members last week rejected a 5.5% pay deal

title: UPEN blog - Chloe Corbyn's reflections as new Senedd Knowledge Exchange Lead
description: In this blog, Chloe Corbyn shares her reflections as the new Senedd Knowledge Exchange Lead.

title: UPEN-Government Pairing Scheme for knowledge mobiliser
description: The scheme aims to enhance cooperation between universities and government by connecting knowledge mobilisers—those facilitating engagement between research and policy. This scheme is open to individuals at any career stage within UPEN member universities in research-policy engagement roles, including academics, professional services, and technical staff. Deadline: 11 April (Use a university email address)

title: Nursery World - How a project with families is boosting children's writing right from the start
description: How an early writing project has been working with researchers, schools and communities to encourage the literacy skills of children.

title: REF 2029 Event - Engagement and Impact policy deep dive
description: 5-6 June 2025, London Those developing the policy framework want to harness stakeholder perspectives as they analyse different policy options. You can contribute to the co-development of the REF 2029 Engagement and Impact (E&I) policy and guidance if you sign up for this event. Topics will likely include the definition of engagement and its role in the assessment framework. To register your interest, please send a short email to info@ref.ac.uk using the subject 'REF E&I policy deep dive'. Deadline to apply: 6 May 2025

title: NHS Confederation - Alleviating child poverty – a shared endeavour: the critical role Integrated Care Systems (ICSs) can play in the government's child poverty strategy
description: Exploring how the government can ensure systems are used to their full potential as part of the child poverty strategy.

title: Children's Commissioner blog - No child should be homeless: how housing instability affects a child's GCSE grades
description: The analysis uses DfE data on pupils' postcode changes and GCSE exam results. The findings, for pupils in Year 11 in academic year 2022/23, show that pupils whose home postcode never changed between Reception and Year 11 were those most likely to get five GCSEs passes, including English and maths, with 65% achieving this. Pupils with less stable housing did less well: just half (50%) of those with three home moves over their school career achieved 5 GCSEs including English and maths; and just over one-in-ten (11%) of those with ten moves.

title: The Guardian - Nearly 20 councils in England 'at risk of insolvency' due to SEND costs
description: Exclusive: Councils say multibillion-pound debts caused by years of overspends on special educational needs support

title: How to build resilient schools: place-based approaches to supporting teachers and leaders
description: nan

title: 19 May 2025, 5:30 pm–7:00 pm.
description: Speakers Toby Greany, Nottingham University Steph Ainsworth, Manchester Metropolitan University Respondents Qing Gu, UCL Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield Mary Lowery, Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland In this latest edition of the What matters in education? panel discussion, Toby Greany and Steph Ainsworth will discuss their research into developing place-based approaches to school leadership development and tools that schools can use to improve teacher resilience and retention. An opportunity to reflect on the implications of their emerging findings for education policy and practice will follow, in conversation with Qing Gu, Professor of Leadership in Education at UCL; Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield and Mary Lowery Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland. Book your place A reminder that the ESRC Education Research Programme ECR Network cordially invites you for a special open session, featuring a panel of speakers on AI and the implications for teaching and learning in schools.

theme: Investigating the recruitment and retention of ethnic minority teachers PI: Stephen Gorard
title: The Conversation - Children from poorer families do worse at school – here's how to understand the disadvantage gap
description: Nadia Siddiqui, School of Education, Durham University and Ceri Brown, University of Bath,

title: NEU - How does teachers' pay compare with that for other professions?
description: Teachers' earnings consistently rank lower than those for most other professional groups. At some career stages, especially early on, teachers start off comparatively well, but soon fall behind. This is despite relatively higher increases to teachers' starting salaries under successive recent pay awards. The gap grows at the upper end of the earnings scale.

title: IOE blog - The future of AI in high stakes testing: the fairness question
description: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming high stakes testing in different parts of the education system. But how do candidates experience these tests? Are they trusted as fair and reliable measures?

title: The Guardian - More than 90% of schools in England ban mobile phone use, survey shows
description: Head of National Education Union calls for statutory ban on phones in schools and social media ban for under-16s

title: House of Lords Library research briefing - Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill
description: A summary of the changes proposed in the Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill has been published by the House of Lords - it is scheduled for second reading in the House of Lords on 1 May 2025. The bill would make a number of changes to children's social care and schools. Read the summary here:

title: CCT members roundtable events
description: CCT have been running a series of roundtable events for their members on the Ofsted consultation, in support of The Teaching Commission and as part of their Rethinking Curriculum campaign. The latest, DfE Primary Curriculum Roundtable for members and Fellows of the college will be co-hosted with Sir Kevan Collins. More They have also just published a blog on The power of community engagement in our schools , a contribution to resetting the agenda in education, using the professional voice.

title: Commons Housing and Local Govt Committee - England's homeless children: the crisis in temporary accommodation
description: Over 164,000 children are currently living in temporary accommodation across England, the highest number on record

title: Education Wales blog - Putting Teachers at the Heart of School Improvement: What the New Partnership Approach Means
description: The School Improvement Partnership Programme is a response to feedback from practitioners that will reduce complexity in the system by creating genuine partnerships with more classroom resources; clearer support structures; a stronger voice from practitioners in how improvement happens; and more collaboration with colleagues

title: The Guardian - Northern Ireland's public services 'at risk of collapse'
description: Hospital waiting lists among worst in UK and children with special needs waiting a year for support, report finds

title: OECD - Constructing Scenarios for the Future of Teaching in Wales
description: A report from the OECD on The New Professionalism and the Future of Teaching project that they have been running in Wales. Key themes of collaborative, connective professionalism, diversity in career pathways, career-long professional learning

title: Department for Science, Innovation & Technology Corporate Report- DSIT research and development (R&D) allocations for 2025/2026
description: Break down of DSITs allocation of research funding monies to ESRC and other research councils

title: Harvard Graduate School of Education - Measuring What Matters
description: There is more to preschool than learning your ABCs and 123s Harvard researchers propose broader range of skills for assessing early education Oxford University is looking for an "experienced researcher interested in leading the development of a collaborative, policy-engaged research agenda that will have meaningful impact in Oxfordshire". Signs of a move towards forming local partnerships between universities and their immediate communities that may provide new avenues for research.

title: UK Parliament POST horizon scanning – Special educational needs and disabilities
description: Opportunities for support and barriers to access

title: Centre for Mental Health report - Invest in childhood
description: Priorities for preventing mental ill health among children and young people

title: They have also just published a blog on The power of community engagement in our schools , a contribution to resetting the agenda in education, using the professional voice.
description: nan

title: Oxford University is looking for an "experienced researcher interested in leading the development of a collaborative, policy-engaged research agenda that will have meaningful impact in Oxfordshire". Signs of a move towards forming local partnerships between universities and their immediate communities that may provide new avenues for research.

title: Do you find this newsletter useful? Are you happy with its frequency? Which section do you find most useful? Any pressing topics we haven't covered? Any good sources of information you think we're missing? How could we improve? We advocate for listening to different stakeholders and so we want your views too!
description: Answer these short questions

title: Event - How to build resilient schools: place-based approaches to supporting teachers and leaders
description: 19 May 2025, 5:30 pm–7:00 pm online Speakers Toby Greany, Nottingham University Steph Ainsworth, Manchester Metropolitan University Respondents Qing Gu, UCL Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield Mary Lowery, Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland In this latest edition of the What matters in education? panel discussion, Toby Greany and Steph Ainsworth will discuss their research into developing place-based approaches to school leadership development and tools that schools can use to improve teacher resilience and retention. An opportunity to reflect on the implications of their emerging findings for education policy and practice will follow, in conversation with Qing Gu, Professor of Leadership in Education at UCL; Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield and Mary Lowery Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland. Book your place

title: AI in Education: From chalkboards to chatbots, does anything really change?
description: Catch up with the ESRC Education Research Programme ECR Network open session, which featured a panel of speakers on AI and the implications for teaching and learning in schools. See the video

theme: Investigating the recruitment and retention of ethnic minority teachers PI: Stephen Gorard
title: Event - Understanding Research Evidence in Education: What Counts as Evidence and how to get evidence into use
description: 9 May 9 - 10am (Online) This workshop will discuss different types of research designs and the kinds of evidence they generate for different purposes. The team will demonstrate how policymakers and practitioners can use a simple framework to judge if any kind of evidence is trustworthy. This is the first step in understanding evidence. The team will also illustrate how use of evidence may be best achieved. Zoom link – use the link to join at 9am on 9 May 2025

title: National Audit Office report - Government's 6,500-teacher pledge faces uncertainties as student numbers surge
description: The NAO has several recommendations to help DfE address the continuing challenges with teacher recruitment and retention, including: Extend its evidence base on what works to recruit and retain teachers, and analyse the costs and benefits of initiatives in helping to decide where to prioritise resource Assess the extent to which the further education workforce model is fit for purpose Read the report Guardian coverage

title: LSE Event - Beyond the Paycheck: Small Class Sizes, Wellbeing Perks, and Work-Life Balance Can Attract Teachers
description: 12 May 2pm – 3pm (online) This event will discuss a study on job attributes that make teaching roles more appealing, focusing on recruitment and retention challenges. It involved experiments with 10,000 teachers and 700 headteachers in England, using qualitative data to provide insights into teacher preferences, leadership perspectives, and the conditions shaping the education labor market. Zoom link to join

title: Teacher Tapp and SchoolDash - Teacher Recruitment and Retention in 2025
description: Social disadvantage and teacher labour market dynamics

title: HEPI blog - Another year, another teacher supply crisis...
description: John Cater revisits a quarter-century of teacher education policy to consider how we can solve the teacher supply crisis

title: The Guardian - Finland restricts use of mobile phones during school day
description: Nordic country is latest to act amid evidence of impact on young people, including attention and self-esteem

title: Institute for Government - Will the government-backed 'starting reception' guide help school readiness?
description: A new checklist to help parents prepare their child for reception is useful – but must be part of a broader package of support.

title: 25/26 will be Rachel de Souza's penultimate year as Children's Commissioner, and will mark 20 years since the establishment of the office.
description: Planned work includes 'Mapping Childhood', using four years of research to pinpoint the best places to grow up in England

title: Alternative Big Listen - ABC respond to Ofsted accepting things need to be simplified
description: TES - Ofsted report cards 'unfit for purpose', finds 'alternative' consultation TES - Ofsted's inspection changes should be thrown out

title: Education Wales blog - Embedding the Enabling Learning Guidance in Wales
description: a blog introducing the Enabling learning National Network Conversations (NNC) which welcomed practitioners from across Wales to share how they are applying the new guidance in their settings.

title: Scottish Government Statistic publication - Additional child poverty analysis 2025
description: The Scottish government publishes statistical data and additional analysis of child poverty and how it has changed over time for a range of subgroups, updated for 2025

title: Belfast Telegraph - 400 special education pupils still waiting on NI school places for September are being failed, says MLA
description: Although the number still waiting for places to be confirmed is less than half of that of this time last year, the numbers of parents still waiting to hear where their child will be attending school is still concerning.

title: Hechinger report - A treasure trove of education reports and studies is under threat
description: Funding for the US Education Department's online library, ERIC, is slated to end

title: Elsevier & Sense about Science webinar series for researchers - Confidence in Communicating Research
description: These webinars, co-created with research leaders, ECRs and science organizations, aim to equip researchers to tackle misinformation and convey complex topics like research integrity and uncertainty. Each webinar also offers resources and training collated from partners around the world. Foundation for Education Development (FED) survey – Seeking stakeholder views from across the education sector –educators, leaders, parents/carers, learners, and all stakeholders – take part in the FED National Education Consultation Survey 2025 The survey will help shape a long-term vision for education in England and inform the recommendations the FED take to government and policy influencers in the months ahead. Survey

title: SMF - We used to have it all: is there a trade-off between wellbeing and attainment in schools?
description: By 2022 the UK had seen the largest fall in pupils' sense of belonging in school of any country in the OECD's Programme for International Student Assessment. Through a literature review and new analysis of OECD data, this briefing paper argues that attainment would not be compromised by placing more emphasis on wellbeing, as some have suggested; and sets out the steps government should take to address this, arguing that this would lessen the current high levels of pupil absence in England.

title: SchoolsWeek - Health must shoulder more SEND accountability, experts tell MPs
description: 7 findings from health experts at the education committee inquiry into SEND Catch up with the session on ParliamentTV

title: Sutton Trust - Cuts to staffing, equipment and tutoring budgets will hit lower income students the hardest
description: Schools are cutting budgets, including on staff, and using Pupil Premium (PP) to plug budget gaps, while less than 10 percent of school leaders say PP funding is enough to fully support eligible pupils.

theme: Decentring the 'resilient teacher': exploring interactions between individuals and their social ecologies PI: Steph Ainsworth
title: The Manchester Met team have been busy sharing their research on teacher resilience at the Comparative and International Education Society Conference (Chicago) and ResilienceCon (Nashville). The key finding related to each paper are summarised below.
description: nan

title: Event - How to build resilient schools: place-based approaches to supporting teachers and leaders
description: 19 May 2025, 5:30 pm–7:00 pm online Speakers Toby Greany, Nottingham University Steph Ainsworth, Manchester Metropolitan University Respondents Qing Gu, UCL Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield Mary Lowery, Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland In this latest edition of the What matters in education? panel discussion, Toby Greany and Steph Ainsworth will discuss their research into developing place-based approaches to school leadership development and tools that schools can use to improve teacher resilience and retention. An opportunity to reflect on the implications of their emerging findings for education policy and practice will follow, in conversation with Qing Gu, Professor of Leadership in Education at UCL; Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield and Mary Lowery Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland. Book your place

title: Event - Digital Citizenship in Schools
description: Tuesday 13 May, 3.30-4.15pm (online) The Teaching for Digital Citizenship project has been working with teachers, young people, ethicists and the EdTech sector across the 4 nations of the UK, to understand the aims, practices and challenges in recovering a space for moral agency in a post-digital world. This online event will set out a data justice approach, in which all young people have a right to information integrity. Our current information ecosystem is not inevitable, it is a product of technical and social conditions which can be acted upon and changed. Drawing on examples of leading practice across the curriculum from our project so far, this webinar will introduce a self-evaluation resource which has been co-designed with teachers in our community of practice. Sign up via Teams

title: SchoolsWeek - Is teacher recruitment showing 'green shoots' of recovery?
description: New analysis this week provides a double boost for promises to solve teacher recruitment woes

title: The FED event- The Ethics Advantage: Building Trust in Turbulent Times
description: 11 June 8–11am, The Historic Dockyard, Chatham, Kent Join Dr. Matt Silver and Mandy Gage in conversation with Jo Malone to explore how ethical leadership can shape the future of education. Ethical leadership helps restore trust, model integrity, and build cultures where both staff and students thrive. Ethical leaders guide difficult decisions with a moral compass, prioritise wellbeing, and foster inclusive environments that reflect and support diverse communities.

title: The Guardian - 'The crux of all evil': what happened to the first city that tried to ban smartphones for under-14s?
description: It's a year since teachers in St Albans asked parents not to give younger children smartphones. How successful have they been? What do the kids think about it? And has it made the adults think about their own 'addiction'?

title: NEU report - "Are you on slide 8 yet?"
description: The impact of standardised curricula on teacher professionalism

title: SchoolsWeek - Oh Lord: Peers now take aim at schools bill
description: SchoolsWeek coverage of a range of opinions in the House of Lords, for and against the children's wellbeing and schools bill

title: DfE statistics - The number of school suspensions and exclusions are up 12% and 2% respectively
description: Levels of suspension and permanent exclusion in the spring term 2023 to 2024 by school type, and reasons for exclusions and suspensions.

title: Institute for Government report - Reducing school absence: Innovation lessons from the last Labour government
description: This report, written by Moira Wallace, former director of the Social Exclusion Unit set up by Tony Blair, is the first in a new series of case studies exploring how Labour can learn from its experience of tackling complex problems when it was last in government.

title: Education NI - Independent Review of Teacher Workload Panel announced
description: Education Minister Paul Givan has announced the independent panel to undertake the Review of Teacher Workload. The panel will examine all aspects of workload faced by teachers and school leaders and will make recommendations for the way forward.

title: Education Scotland - New Curriculum Improvement Cycle mini podcast series
description: Education Scotland is leading a systematic review of the Scottish curriculum called the Curriculum Improvement Cycle, to ensure it remains up to date and relevant for children and young people.

title: London Universities' Council for Academic Freedom - REF 2029 Briefing Note
description: This briefing note argues that REF 2029 proposals significantly shift focus away from research quality by reducing the weighting of research outputs and introducing a heavily bureaucratic and controversial 'People, Culture and Environment' (PCE) component, with limited sector consultation and unclear evidence of benefit.

title: CAPE - Hidden Talents: Core Competencies of Knowledge Mobilisers Working in Public Policy
description: A report exploring the skills of those who work in roles supporting knowledge transfer between research and public policy.

title: DfE seeking new chief scientific adviser. Details of the role can be found on the Civil Service World
description: nan

title: NSPCC report - Children's services spending reports
description: As spending on early intervention and preventative support has decreased, spending on late intervention services – when families have already reached crisis point – has risen to record levels.

title: NAHT - 4 in 5 school leaders struggling to meet the needs of pupils with SEND due to lack of specialist provision
description: School leaders' union NAHT releases the results of a snap poll of its members showing that 4 out of 5 respondents have pupils in mainstream classes whose needs should be being met in specialist provision because of a lack of availability of specialist places.

An opportunity to reflect on the implications of their emerging findings for education policy and practice will follow, in conversation with Qing Gu, Professor of Leadership in Education at UCL; Stephen Betts, Chief Executive of Learn Sheffield and Mary Lowery Head of School Improvement (Post-primary and Special Education, Locality East), Education Authority Northern Ireland. Book your place

title: DfE Press release - Red tape slashed to get more teachers into classrooms
description: Government announces cuts to the duration of school-based apprenticeships to get thousands of more teachers into the classroom. SchoolsWee k

title: EEF Practice Review - Mapping professional development and support programmes in the early years sector
description: This review has identified a complex and multi-layered early years professional development and support programmes landscape. Whilst multiple programmes have been identified, demand remains high and there is a need to improve awareness of and engagement in programmes to support the sector in improving children's outcomes Early Years Alliance comment

title: National Education Union - Artificial intelligence (AI) in schools checklist |
description: The aim of this policy checklist on AI is to support reps negotiating the introduction of AI with their employer or school.

title: AI speeds up special needs reports
description: Stoke-on-Trent City Council is leveraging AI to reduce waiting times for children's special needs reports, specifically education, health and care plans (EHCPs). In 2023-24, only 43% of EHCPs were completed within the target of 60%, leading to delays in support for families. Delyth Mathieson, assistant director of education and family support, explained that AI tools are now trained to extract information from various reports, streamlining the process. "What we're looking at is a process whereby we can upload those reports... so that the information is collated and dropped into the format automatically and intelligently," she stated. The council has also cleared its backlog, with provisional figures showing that 83% of EHCPs were issued within 20 weeks in April. More

title: SchoolsWeek - Schools wanted for AI lesson planning trial
description: Education Endowment Foundation study to assess whether AI tool can save teachers time while not compromising on quality

title: Institute for Government - Policy making for left-behind groups: School readiness
description: How can government start closing the opportunity gap in early years education? "School readiness" is a contested term, but this IFG report is setting out some of the issues and asking for evidence

title: SchoolsWeek - SEND monitoring inspections to restart this term, says Ofsted
description: Education committee MPs also hear calls for school exclusion investigations and schools bill fears

title: 2025-26 Scottish Government Education Research Seminar Series - Call for papers is now open
description: The Scottish Government has issued an open invitation to education researchers for 15 minute presentations on c ollaborative research, international comparative research and papers synthesising the existing evidence base on a particular policy or issue. Likely topics include: Attainment; health and wellbeing; curriculum; education reform; education workforce;ongoing impact of COVID-19; UNCRC; and studies drawing on Scottish administrative data. For more information and to submit an 300 word abstract via Microsoft Forms, please click here Deadline: 13 June. If you have any questions, please get in touch with Dr Clare Magill - clare.magill@gov.scot .

title: Education Scotland - Pupil Equity Funding 2025 Report
description: This latest report deepens the understanding of how Pupil Equity Funding improves outcomes for children and young people impacted by poverty, with a focus on tackling the poverty-related attainment gap.

title: Welsh Government Cabinet Office - Written Statement: Funding to support organisations to work together to address child poverty
description: Child poverty is a cross-cutting policy issue, and the Welsh Government have tried to reflect this in the diversity of projects which have secured funding from this grant award process.

title: Public Policy design blog on gov.uk - Designing policy with complex evidence
description: Evidence-based policy making relies on robust, diverse research insights to inform policy ideas and decision making. But that's easier said than done, particularly for complex policy challenges with evidence that contains many different actors and factors influencing the outcomes.

title: National Audit Office Value for Money report - UK Research and Innovation: providing support through grants
description: This report examines how UKRI puts into practice the principles and conditions for effective support for R&I in the UK and what more could be done to support good decision-making

title: Bill Gates has announced plans to wind down his foundation and spend $200bn on global health, climate and poverty prevention by 2045
description: nan

title: Chartered College of Teaching - Catch up on the video from Rethinking Curriculum – The Power of Place
description: What happens when you put place at the centre of curriculum design – a case study from s chools in Stoke-on-Trent, linking history, engineering, science and careers with the area's role in Operation Spitfire

title: Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG) and Loughborough University's Centre for Research in Social Policy (CRSP) – The minimum cost of education in the UK
description: New report on the minimum cost of education in the UK for parents sending their children to state school. Press release

title: Youth Endowment Fund report- Education Policy, Children and Violence
description: Puts forward eight recommendations for education policymakers to prevent children's involvement in violence in England and Wales, developed in consultation with headteachers, academics and policy experts.

title: The Big Issue - Lord John Bird demands Labour set child poverty reduction targets in Children's Bill amendment
description: The Big Issue founder has put forward an amendment to the Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill to 'hold Labour's feet to the fire' and compel govt to set targets for reducing child poverty

title: SchoolsWee k

title: Do you find this newsletter useful? Are you happy with its frequency? Which section do you find most useful? Any pressing topics we haven't covered? Any good sources of information you think we're missing? How could we improve? We advocate for listening to different stakeholders and so we want your views too!
description: Answer these short questions

title: BERA blog - Beyond research findings: The value of knowledge exchange
description: Gemma Moss Universities are increasingly recognising the value of preparing researchers to engage with other stakeholders. Gemma argues that considering how to engage, whether to engage, with whom and why, is a crucial way of rebalancing in whose interests researchers work.

title: Catch up with the video from 'How to build resilient schools: place-based approaches to supporting teachers and leaders'
description: See the video

title: EPI Webinar: Workforce sustainability in the modern school system
description: 25th June 2025 10:30 This webinar will draw out potential solutions to the recruitment and retention crisis and consider how harnessing the benefits of data and technology can alleviate some of the challenges education staff are facing. This is the first in a series of three webinars, building on the data from EPI's effective school groups tool .

title: WonkHE - The trouble with the latest accreditation round for initial teacher education
description: The Department for Education has opened applications for new ITT accreditation. Megan Stephenson worries lessons haven't been learned from the last go-round

title: SchoolsWeek - DfE chief: 'We can support schools to be more efficient'
description: Quizzed by MPs at a Public Accounts Committee meeting, senior civil servant, Susan Acland-Hood left many questions about school funding and delivering on the government's promise to recruit 6,500 new teachers unanswered.

title: BERJ - Exploring the landscape of GenAI and education literature: A taxonomy of themes and sub ‐ themes
description: Sam Clarke The research landscape surrounding Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) and education is rapidly expanding, characterised by a dynamic array of themes and sub-themes. This paper aims to construct a comprehensive taxonomy that categorises the current literature on the integration of GenAI in educational settings.

title: FED event - Strategy, Ethics & Action: Leading the Digital Shift in Education
description: 25 June, 8:30am to 10:30am, HAYS, 107 Cheapside, London, EC2V 6DN Join Professor Wayne Holmes and Alison Gellett for a thought-provoking deep dive into the current digital transformation situation within the education sector, to examine successes as well as important issues rarely considered, especially within the world of generative AI.

title: Education Secretary, Bridget Phillipson has given a keynote speech on the use of EdTech to improve opportunity in education at the Education World Forum
description: nan

title: Hansard update - Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill debated in the Lords
description: Committee stage, the first chance for line by line examination of the bill, began on Tuesday 20 May.

title: SchoolsWeek - What leaders really want from NPQs (and the review isn't asking)
description: Organisational coach, Shane Leaning, sets out what the government's NPQ review is missing and what it should actually be asking leaders about how the programmes can be improved

title: WonkHE - UKRI has too many people telling it what to do without the resources to do what it's told
description: In response to the NAO report on UKRI, James Coe argues it has been set too many priorities from too many places. He asks if less could be more in building a thriving, inclusive research and innovation system

title: DfE NI - Education Minister launches public consultation on proposal to strengthen inspection legislation
description: Paul Givan has launched a public consultation on proposals to strengthen cooperation with the inspection process across schools and other education and training organisations in Northern Ireland.

title: DfE NI - Education Minister announces extension of the Northern Ireland Childcare Subsidy Scheme to cover school-age children
description: Paul Givan announced a £55 million package of measures for early learning and childcare that will include an extension of the Northern Ireland Childcare Subsidy Scheme to cover school-age children.

title: OECD event - Trends Spotting: How is strategic foresight helping educators and governments plan for the future?
description: 5 June 2025 12noon (Online) A panel of experts talks about how global transformation is shaping education in their own contexts in response to the OECD report, Trends Shaping Education 2025 . They'll look at the report's tools and share tips on how governments, universities and schools can use foresight to anticipate challenges, grasp opportunities and shape education for the better in a rapidly changing world. Register here

title: LPIPs - The Evolving Art of Place Leadership
description: In this blog, Sam Markey emphasises the transformative power of collaborative governance, strategic public procurement, and place-based impact investment in driving local renewal and prosperity amidst economic and social challenges.

title: Co-Production Collective - Measuring Success in Co-production: Learning by Doing programme
description: Some reflections on how to evaluate co-production. The main takeaway: Success in co-production isn't easily measured by numbers or fixed tools. Instead, use flexible resources, ask open questions, and build evaluations that fit your unique project and team.

title: DfE - Almost a million more pupils get access to mental health support, covering six in ten children across the country.
description: What the DfE is doing to enable more pupils to access mental health support - and why whole school initiatives tackling mental health may matter more The Conversation - analysis from Gemma McKenna, University of Birmingham

title: The Guardian - One in four pupils in England 'disengage' when they move to secondary
description: The Guardian reports a drop in enjoyment, trust and feelings of safety after year 7 in pupil survey data collected by ImpactEd and analysed by John Jerrim (UCL). Might this give the Curriculum Review panel in England something to think about as they consider curriculum change in the secondary school?

title: FFT - School absences, exclusions and crime amongst high-achieving children from disadvantaged backgrounds
description: High-achieving disadvantaged pupils consistently have higher absence rates than their equally able but more socio-economically advantaged peers. This blog post considers the implications.

title: This is the first in a series of three webinars, building on the data from EPI's effective school groups tool .

description: Answer these short questions

title: Event: Developing pedagogies in early years and primary school settings: opportunities and challenges in different policy contexts.
description: 26 June 2025, 5:30 pm–7:00 pm Speakers Sarah Chicken, University of the West of England Alison Porter, University of Southampton Respondents Sinead Harmey, UCL Associate Professor in Literacy Education Bernadette Holmes MBE, Director, National Consortium for Languages Education In the next What Matters in Education? webinar, Sarah Chicken and Alison Porter will discuss the approaches they have used to develop innovative pedagogic practice in early years and primary settings against a backdrop of policy change. In Wales, children's participative rights are now part of the early years curriculum framework; in England, learning a Modern Foreign Language has become part of primary KS 2, although a Curriculum and Assessment Review is now underway. Join us for a discussion of the implications of their research in conversation with Sinead Harmey and Bernadette Holmes. Book your place

title: BERA blog - We need a revolution in the primary curriculum for England, not an evolution
description: Sarah Seleznyov, Co-headteacher at School 360

title: Teacher Pay
description: The government has accepted recommendations on teachers pay from the STRB, but schools will be expected to find approximately the first 1% of pay awards through improved productivity and smarter spending. SchoolsWeek analyses five key findings on the teacher workforce from The School Teachers' Review Body's Report

title: The Guardian - Estonia eschews phone bans in schools and takes leap into AI
description: Estonia is launching a national initiative called AI Leap , which it says will equip students and teachers with "world-class artificial intelligence tools and skills". Teachers will be trained in the technology, focusing on self-directed learning and digital ethics, and prioritising educational equity and AI literacy. Officials say it will make Estonia "one of the smartest AI-using nations, not just the most tech-saturated".

title: OECD event - The teaching profession reimagined: From classroom innovation to system-level transformation
description: 10 June 3pm (London time) Drawing on insights from the OECD's New Professionalism and the Future of Teaching project, this webinar will bring together educators and researchers to explore how innovation can take root and thrive in classrooms, across schools and throughout entire education systems. Register here

title: IFS report
description: A report on the upcoming Spending Review, with a particular focus on the likely impacts on schools and colleges and the choices and challenges facing education policymakers IFS report - Schools and colleges in the 2025 Spending Review

title: Education Select Committee – Government response to Children's Wellbeing and Schools Bill
description: nan

title: LPIPs blog post - Putting the 'Policy' into Local Policy and Innovation Partnership: Political Engagement and Cymru Wledig LPIP Rural Wales
description: nan

title: Department of Health NI - Public consultation on Children's and Young People's Emotional Health and Wellbeing Framework
description: The Health Minister has launched a 14-week public consultation on a draft Children's and Young People's Emotional Health and Wellbeing Framework.

title: HEPI blog - Only connect: why investing in relational infrastructure is critical for universities
description: Sarah Chaytor "There is a need to focus more on how universities can make human connections and articulate their research benefit in human terms and show how universities are putting their considerable assets and resources to use for the public good."

title: Office for Science - Routes for academic engagement with Government
description: Guide on how to use academic expertise to make an impact on national priorities. This can range from responding to one of the government's areas of research interest to undertaking an internship, fellowship or apprenticeship.

title: REF 2029's sub-panels leaders announced
description: The four UK higher education funding bodies, working with the REF Main Panel Chairs and Advisory Panel members, welcome the chairs and deputy chairs for the 34 expert sub-panels that will assess research in REF 2029.

title: The Conversation - Teachers knew what children needed to recover from the pandemic – but their insights were ignored
description: Gemma Moss & Alice Bradbury A blog post exploring why many of the long-term effects of school closures during COVID have been misdiagnosed. Five years on, it is not in the areas of learning loss that the long-term effects are being most felt, but in the complex interactions between pupil absence and exclusions, the ongoing impacts on children with special educational needs and the impacts on pupil wellbeing.

title: NurseryWorld - Government commits £3.4m in funding to early language support programme to help 20,000 more children
description: The Early Language Support for Every Child (ELSEC) programme deploys specialist teams across early years settings and primary schools to help identify and respond to children's speech and language needs, with a focus on children with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND).

title: SchoolsWeek investigates SEND reforms:
description: 'If SEND isn't fixed now - it will become so broken and big, it never gets resolved', says one source. But parents are already 'panicked'. Meanwhile, many councils aren't passing on the funding allocated for high needs at last year's budget

title: SchoolsWeek analyses five key findings on the teacher workforce from The School Teachers' Review Body's Report
